overview: This subject teaches students to conceptualise and undertake an ethnographic research project on music-making in the contemporary world.

Through in-class activities, students learn to make fieldnotes, engage in participant-observation, conduct interviews, and use performance as a research tool. Through weekly readings, students learn to assess and navigate ethical issues related to research and writing about musicians and listeners. The subject is especially designed for students considering graduate research in music.
ilo: find and assess the secondary literature in the disciplines of ethnomusicology and anthropology;
articulate and formulate responses to the main issues involved in undertaking music ethnography;
demonstrate understanding of the ethical problems that music scholars encounter;
select and use specific ethnographic methods to research music-making;
craft a viable research question and plan for undertaking research in the discipline of ethnomusicology.
generic_skills: an understanding of different cultural values;
a capacity for independent thought and critical analysis;
the capacity to write in a scholarly manner appropriate to the discipline;

Prerequisites.content: Note: these can be taken concurrently (at the same time)

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: Written responses to reading assignments, due every second week
An annotated bibliography of ten sources
A research proposal draft (excluding bibliography and discography)
Two short ethnographic exercises due in Weeks 6 and 10
A revised final research proposal (excluding bibliography and discography)

date_times.contact_hours: 24 hours, comprising one 2-hour seminar per week.
